argumentText:
We want to prove $$\frac{CP}{PF} =\frac{CD}{DB} +\frac{CE}{EA}$$

![image](aubel)

On the picture, let us call $\phi$ to the angle $\angle ABE$ and $\psi$
to the angle $\angle EBC$.

A generalization of bisector’s theorem states
$$\frac{CE}{EA} = \frac{CB \sin \psi}{AB\sin\phi} \quad\mbox{on }\triangle ABC$$
and
$$\frac{CP}{PF} = \frac{CB \sin \psi}{FB\sin\phi} \quad\mbox{on }\triangle FBC.$$
From the two equalities we can get
$$\frac{CE\cdot AB}{EA}=\frac{CP\cdot FB}{PF}$$ and thus
$$\frac{CP}{PF}=\frac{CE\cdot AB}{EA\cdot FB}.$$ Since $AB=AF+FB$,
substituting leads to $$\begin{aligned}
\frac{CE\cdot AB}{EA\cdot FB}&=\frac{CE(AF+FB)}{EA\cdot FB}\\
&=\frac{CE\cdot AF}{EA\cdot FB}+\frac{CE\cdot FB}{EA\cdot FB}\\
&=\frac{CE\cdot AF}{EA\cdot FB}+\frac{CE}{EA}\end{aligned}$$

But Ceva’s theorem states
$$\frac{CE}{EA}\cdot\frac{AF}{FB}\cdot\frac{BD}{DC}=1$$ and so
$$\frac{CE\cdot AF}{EA\cdot FB}=\frac{CD}{DB}$$ Subsituting the last
equality gives the desired result.
